text:
Functions of responsible officers
	Appointment of taxing officers
		The responsible officer of each House of Parliament must appoint a personto be the taxing officer of that House.
		The taxing officer—
			is to hold and vacate office according to the terms of his appointment, and
			must act according to any directions he receives from his responsibleofficer.
		“Responsible officer” means—
			in relation to the House of Commons, the Speaker, and
			in relation to the House of Lords, the Clerk of the Parliaments (or, in hisabsence, the Clerk Assistant).
	Authorisation of representatives' charges
		The responsible officer of each House of Parliament may prepare a listwhich specifies—
			matters relating to proceedings of that House on private Bills and forwhich representatives may charge costs, and
			the amount of costs which they may charge for each matter.
		On an assessment of costs under this Act, a taxing officer may not allowcosts for a matter specified under subsection (1)(a) in so far as they exceedthe amount specified for that matter under subsection (1)(b).
		But he may allow reasonable costs for a matter which—
			relates to the proceedings, but
			is not specified under subsection (1)(a).

Assessment of disputed costs
	Application for assessment
		Either of the following may apply for an assessment of costs relating toproceedings of Parliament on a private Bill—
			a representative (or a successor of his) to whom payment of the costs isoverdue,
			a party who has been charged with, but who objects to, the costs.
		Subsection (1) does not apply unless the representative (or a partner orsuccessor of his) has signed a bill of the costs and—
			delivered it to the party, or
			sent it by post to, or left it for him at, his workplace, home or lastknown home address.
		The application must be made—
			where the proceedings took place in only one House, to the taxing officerof that House;
			where they took place in both Houses, to either taxing officer.
		The application must be accompanied by a true copy of the bill of costs.
		If, pending an assessment of costs on an application under this section,proceedings are brought to recover the costs, those proceedings are stayeduntil the costs have been certified under section 8.
	Duty to assess: general
		A taxing officer who receives an application under section 3 must assessthe costs to which the application relates (except in so far as they are to beassessed by another officer as a result of section 5).
		Subsection (1) does not apply in the case of an application within section3(1)(b) if—
			before the application is made, judgment is obtained in proceedings for therecovery of the costs, or
			the application is made after the end of the period of six months beginningwith the day on which the bill of costs is delivered, sent or left inaccordance with section 3(2).
		But if, in the case of an application within section 3(1)(b) made after theend of that period, the taxing officer informs his responsible officer ofspecial circumstances, the responsible officer may, having regard to thatinformation, direct the taxing officer to assess the costs to which theapplication relates.
	Duty to assess: special cases
		Subsection (2) applies where—
			the taxing officer of one House receives an application under section 3,and
			the bill of costs to which the application relates includes costs whichrelate to a private Bill but not to proceedings of that House.
		The taxing officer may—
			assess the costs himself, or
			ask the taxing officer of the other House or an authorised court officer toassess some or all of them.
		Subsection (5) applies where—
			an officer is asked under subsection (2)(b) to assess costs, or
			the Secretary of State asks the taxing officer of the House of Commons toassess costs relating to a Bill or to a provisional order.
		Subsection (5) also applies where an authorised court officer asks eithertaxing officer to assess costs—
			relating to a private Bill, and
			included in a bill of costs which the authorised officer is directed toassess by the court by which he is authorised.
		The officer concerned must—
			assess the costs, and
			give his opinion to the person who asked him to assess them.
		An authorised court officer may—
			for the purpose of assessing costs under this section, exercise any powershe has for the purpose of assessing costs under his authority, and
			receive fees for assessing costs under this section on the same basis as hewould for assessing costs under his authority.
		“Authorised court officer” means an officer of a court who is authorised bythat court to assess costs relating to its proceedings.
	Report to responsible officer
		After the assessment of costs on an application under section 3, the taxingofficer must, if required to do so by the representative (or his successor) orthe party, report the assessment to his responsible officer.
		The report must specify—
			the amount of costs allowed on the assessment,
			how much of that amount has yet to be paid, and
			the amount of costs payable for carrying out the assessment.
		Where the amount specified for the purposes of subsection (2)(a) includesan amount for costs assessed under section 5, that amount may be specified inthe report and certified under section 8.
	Complaints about report
		This section applies where—
			a taxing officer reports an assessment of costs under section 6, and
			the representative (or his successor) or the party wishes to complain aboutthe report.
		The person wishing to complain may give a statement of his complaint to theresponsible officer of the House concerned.
		The statement must be given to the responsible officer before the end ofthe applicable period.
		The responsible officer may—
			give the report and the statement to the taxing officer, and
			require him to make a further report on the assessment.
		On receiving that further report, the responsible officer may require thetaxing officer to amend the report to which the statement of complaintrelates.
		In this section and section 8, “applicable period”, in relation to a reportunder section 6, means the period of 21 days beginning with the day after theone on which the report is made.
	Certificate by responsible officer
		This section applies where—
			at the end of the applicable period, no statement of complaint has beengiven under section 7, or
			any matters complained of in a statement given under that section have beenfinally disposed of.
		If the representative or party applies to the responsible officer for acertificate of costs, the responsible officer must certify to him the amountof the costs.
		The certificate is to be treated for the purposes of any proceedings asconclusive evidence of—
			the matters to which the costs relate,
			the amount of costs allowed on the assessment,
			how much of that amount has, as at the date of the certificate, yet to bepaid, and
			the amount of costs payable for carrying out the assessment.
		Subsection (5) applies where, in proceedings to recover costs certifiedunder this section, the defendant says he is not liable to pay them (or partof them).
		The certificate is to be treated for the purposes of any proceedings asconclusive evidence only of such amount (if any) as the claimant may recoverfrom the defendant as a result of the proceedings mentioned in subsection (4).

Vexatious proceedings
	Award of costs to promoter of private Bill
		This section applies where, in proceedings of Parliament on a private Bill,a committee of either House—
			decides that the preamble to the Bill is proved, and
			unanimously reports that the promoter has been vexatiously exposed to costsas a result of opposition to the Bill by one or more petitioners.
		The promoter may recover from the petitioner (or, where there is more thanone, those specified by the committee)—
			such portion as the committee specifies of the promoter’s costs ofpromoting the Bill (subject to their assessment under section 12), or
			if the committee specifies an amount in respect of those costs and theparties affected agree to it, that amount.
		The committee must specify in its report—
			the portion or amount of costs recoverable under this section,
			who must pay that portion or amount, and
			who may recover it.
		A landowner who at his own risk and cost opposes a private Bill whichproposes the acquisition of any part of his property is not liable under thissection for any costs in respect of his opposition.
		For the purposes of this section and section 10, a committee is to beregarded as reporting unanimously if its report is made by every member of itpresent.
	Award of costs to petitioner opposing private Bill
		This section applies where, in proceedings of Parliament on a private Bill,a committee of either House—
			decides that the preamble to the Bill is not proved, or amends the Bill soas to protect a petitioner who opposes it, and
			unanimously reports that a petitioner who opposes the Bill has beenunreasonably or vexatiously exposed to costs in defending rights of his withwhich the Bill proposes to interfere.
		A petitioner of the kind mentioned in subsection (1)(b) may recover fromthe promoter—
			the amount of the petitioner’s costs (subject to their assessment undersection 12) for defending rights of his of the kind mentioned in subsection(1)(b),
			if the committee specifies a portion of those costs, that portion, or
			if the committee specifies an amount in respect of those costs and theparties affected agree to it, that amount.
		The committee must specify in its report—
			the portion or amount of costs recoverable under this section,
			who must pay that portion or amount, and
			who may recover it.
	Application for assessment etc. on award of vexatious costs
		A person entitled to recover costs under section 9(2)(a) or 10(2)(a) or (b)may apply for their assessment and certification.
		A person entitled to recover costs under section 9(2)(b) or 10(2)(c) mayapply only for their certification.
		The application must be made to the taxing officer of the House to whichthe members of the committee awarding the costs belong.
		The application—
			must be made before the end of the period of six months beginning with thedate of the committee’s report, but
			if made under subsection (1), must not be made before the end of the periodof one month beginning with the day on which a duly signed bill of the costsis delivered to the person required to pay those costs.
		“Duly signed”, in relation to a bill of costs, means signed (or, whereappropriate, sealed) by or on behalf of the applicant.
	Duty to assess and certify vexatious costs
		Where a taxing officer receives an application under section 11(1), he mustassess and certify the costs to which the application relates.
		Where a taxing officer receives an application under section 11(2), he mustcertify the costs to which the application relates.
		The certificate must specify—
			the amount of costs recoverable (“the recoverable costs”),
			the person entitled to recover that amount (“the entitled person”),
			any person liable to pay it (“the liable person”), and
			the extent to which he is liable to do so (“the specified extent”).
		The certificate is to be treated for the purposes of any proceedings asconclusive evidence of—
			the recoverable costs, and
			the right of the entitled person to recover those costs from the liableperson to the specified extent.
		The certificate must be—
			signed by the taxing officer giving it, and
			given by him to such of the parties affected as he thinks appropriate.
		The entitled person must, on recovering the recoverable costs, give areceipt at the foot of the certificate; and the receipt discharges theliability to pay the costs.

Powers etc. on assessment
	Functions of taxing officers
		A taxing officer required to assess costs under this Act may—
			take evidence on oath from a party to, or a witness connected with, theproceedings on the assessment;
			require a party to those proceedings to produce documents in his possessionwhich relate to the assessment.
		A taxing officer required to assess costs under section 4 or 5 must—
			hold a hearing for the purpose of carrying out the assessment, and
			give the parties to the proceedings on the assessment reasonable notice ofthe hearing.
		If a party neglects to attend the hearing, it may be held in his absence.
		If costs have been assessed under this Act, the taxing officer may, havingworked out how much of the amount assessed has already been paid, report—
			the amount already paid, and
			any amount still owing.
	Fees 
		A taxing officer may require a party to proceedings on an assessment underthis Act, or a person affected by a certification under this Act, to pay him—
			the costs of carrying out the assessment or certification, and
			an amount equivalent to any fees which he is authorised or required by theorders of the House concerned to charge for carrying it out (or such portionof that amount as he directs).
		If he receives any money under this section, he must apply it according tothe orders of the House.

Miscellaneous
	Application to other types of Bill etc.
		Any function exercisable under section 2, 4, 6, 7 or 8 by the Speaker ortaxing officer of the House of Commons in respect of a private Bill is alsoexercisable by him in respect of—
			the promotion of, or opposition to, a provisional order or provisionalorder Bill;
			the opposition to a hybrid Bill.
		The power under section 3 is exercisable in respect of proceedings of theHouse of Commons on a matter within paragraph (a) or (b) of subsection (1) asit is in respect of proceedings of that House on a private Bill.
		A reference in this Act to an assessment of costs made, or required to bemade, under this Act is accordingly to be read as including a reference to anassessment made, or required to be made, as a result of subsection (1) or (2).
		Sections 9 to 12 apply in relation to a provisional order Bill referred toa select committee of either House as they apply in relation to a privateBill.
		Where section 12 applies as a result of subsection (4), any function whichwould be exercisable under section 13(1) or 14 by a taxing officer in respectof a private Bill is exercisable by him in respect of the provisional orderBill.
	Court of Referees
		The Court of Referees may take evidence on oath on such matters in relation toa private Bill as the Court is entitled under an order of the House of Commonsto investigate.

Final
	Consequential and transitional provisions
		In section 6 of the Private Legislation Procedure (Scotland) Act [1936 (c.52)](/id/ukpga/1936/52?view=plain "Go to item of legislation") (sittings ofCommissioners on provisional orders), in subsection (6), for the words fromthe beginning to the first “shall” substitute “Sections 9 to 12 of theParliamentary Costs Act 2006 shall,”.
		In section 9 of that Act (procedure on bills to confirm provisionalorders), in subsection (3), for “the Parliamentary Costs Act, 1865” substitute“sections 9 to 12 of the Parliamentary Costs Act 2006”.
		In section 7 of the Statutory Orders (Special Procedure) Act [1945 (c.18)](/id/ukpga/1945/18?view=plain "Go to item of legislation") (costs), insubsection (1), for the words from “under the Parliamentary Costs Act 1865” to“the first mentioned Act” substitute “under sections 9 to 12 of theParliamentary Costs Act 2006 (as a result of section 15(4) and (5) of thatAct); and sections 9 to 12 of that Act”.
		In subsection (2) of that section—
			for the words from the beginning to “1849”, substitute “Sections 2 to 8, 13and 14 of that Act”, and
			for the words from “and section two” to the end substitute “and, for thatpurpose, the reference to the Secretary of State in section 5(3) of that Act(which refers to the procedure under which the Secretary of State requests anassessment of costs) is to be read as including a reference to the Minister.”.
		The amendments made by this section have the same extent as the enactmentsto which they relate.
		Schedule 1 contains repeals and revocations.
		Schedule 2 contains transitional provisions.
	Interpretation 
		In this Act—
		  * “costs” includes fees, disbursements and expenses, 
		  * “promoter” means, in the case of a private Bill not promoted by a company— 
			any person named in the Bill as a promoter of it, and
			any company which would, if the provisions of the Bill were in force, beincorporated as a result,
				  * “provisional order” means an order or scheme made under, and requiring confirmation by, Act of Parliament, 
				  * “provisional order Bill” means a Bill to confirm a provisional order, 
				  * “representative” includes a parliamentary agent and a solicitor, 
				  * “responsible officer” has the meaning given by section 1, 
				  * “solicitor” includes a body recognised under section 9 of the Administration of Justice Act [1985 (c. 61)](/id/ukpga/1985/61?view=plain "Go to item of legislation") (incorporated practices) and a reference to a solicitor’s partner includes a director of such a body, and 
				  * “successor”, in relation to a representative, means his executor, administrator or assignee. 
	Commencement, extent and short title
		This Act comes into force on 1st April 2007.
		Subject to section 17(5), this Act extends to Northern Ireland.
		This Act may be cited as the Parliamentary Costs Act 2006.
